awd_titl_txt: Time and Episodic Memory: Neuropsychology Meets Philosophy
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how the capacity to remember past personal experiences contributes to the emergence and maintenance of the sense of time. Individuals with episodic amnesia, that is, amnesia for vivid personal past experiences, are modeled in both science and the popular media as trapped in time. This core metaphor shapes our understanding both of what episodic memory is (mental time travel) and of its role in our lives as people (anchoring us in time). Amnesia is seen accordingly as a pathology affecting an individual’s entire subjective temporality, one that undermines their decisions about the future and scuttles all possibility of autonomous living.  Our work shows that  amnesic individuals are not trapped in time; they are capable of more as moral and practical agents than the trapped-in-time model would lead one to predict.  

We study temporal cognition in individuals with episodic amnesia to learn how episodic memory is involved in cognition about time. Do individuals with amnesia develop and maintain concepts of the  past, present, and future? Do they understand time’s irreversible order or that events can be sequenced earlier to later? Do they care about the difference between the future and the past? Do they discount the value of future rewards, make impulsive choices, or exhibit presentist bias in their practical and moral decisions? Research in our and other labs increasingly reveals that individuals with amnesia are not trapped in time but understand time and its implications well. These findings are transformative for humanists interested in the value of memory in human life, philosophers interested in the source of our knowledge of time,  scientists struggling to understand what memory is and how it contributes to our lives as persons, and, finally, to clinicians trying to help people with memory loss live fuller human lives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project translated scientific results from the study of people with episodic amnesia into philosophical conclusions about the role of episodic memory in our lives as persons. Episodic memory is memory for events accompanied by awareness that you previously experienced the event, such as remembering the last conversation you had with a good friend or the breakfast you had this morning. Our intuitions tell us that this form of memory is central to our sense of who we are, to our ability to make key decisions, and to our ability even to grasp the notion of time in which our lives play out. How, after all, could you form a sense of the passing of time if you could not remember a time prior to now?, one might reasonably ask. 

The novelty in our work lies in treating this bit of intuitive common sense about the centrality of episodic memory to our lives as persons as an empirical hypothesis, one that itself must be responsive to observational and experimental evidence. By showing that people with amnesia are in fact capable of much more than we might expect based on those intuitions, we not only open up a deeper appreciation for how persons are implemented in cognitive systems but, more importantly, we can envision new ways to scaffold the autonomy of people with memory loss. 

Our work on memory, which will now appear in philosophy journals (in addition to publication of the experiments in scientific journals), shows that even people with dense and lifelong amnesias nonetheless maintain a conceptual grasp of time. This includes an appreciation both of the A-series (that time passes, that it has a direction, that the future and past are importantly different in their openness to change from the present, etc.) and of the B-series (that time can be sequenced into events arranged as earlier and later). We also show that people with amnesia preserve the same typical temporal preferences, attitudes, and decision-making tendencies as do neurotypical control. This would all suggest that episodic memory is far less important as a basis for these higher forms of cognition about time than one might have suspected. 

These findings have intellectual merit for both scientists, who tend to adopt the common trope that people with amnesia are trapped in the now, and for philosophers, who generally follow the scientists in this regard.  By integrating the evidential power of neuropsychology with the pressing human questions of philosophy, we have been working to build a transdisciplinary methodology for showing how people work in terms of their cognitive systems. 

We hope that these findings also have broader impacts for people with memory loss. The trapped in time metaphor offers very little hope to people with amnesia. In contrast, if we look away from highly intellectual diagnoses of what people with episodic amnesia have lost and toward more practical effects of their amnesia, we reveal a world of possible interventions that might in some measure restore their autonomy and personhood. Our work is written in an accessible and easy style that will hopefully reach beyond the narrow confines of the academic world to impact how people think about and treat themselves and their loved ones.
